prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. We calculate the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5?. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright and 2-faint and 3-faint) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.3,0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. CO is expected to be detected at the following observed frequencies for objects in this science goal (PACS 787: 91.38 GHz; PACS 472: 88.70 GHz) due to their redshifts (1.523 and 1.599). The total observing time for Sg 1 in band-3 is 34.9 minutes including overheads.

We use four basebands each of width 1.875 GHz. Two bands are set for the detection of the CO (2-1) line while the other two are set to measure the continuum as secondary to our main objective. Our velocity resolution (5.64 km/s) is sufficient to measure line widths (of 400 km/s) and integrated line flux.

We have specified an angular resolution larger than 1 arcsec to measure the total CO emission from our targets and not resolve out any of the emission if observed at higher spatial resolution. The largest angular scales should be 3arcsec since this is larger than the size of our targets. If our targets cannot be observed in configurations C36-1 and C36-2 due to scheduling restrictions, then C36-3 is acceptable at a resolution of 1.2arcsec.

We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. We calculate the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright and 2-faint and 3-faint) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.3, 0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. CO is expected to be detected at the following observed frequencies for objects in SG 2 (PACS 197: 88.67 GHz; PACS 491: 87.42 GHz) due to the redshifts (1.600 and 1.637) given in science justification. The total observing time for Sg 2 in band-3 is 53.43 minutes including overheads.

We use four basebands each of width 1.875 GHz. Two bands are set for the detection of the CO (2-1) line while the other two are set to measure the continuum as secondary to our main objective. Our velocity resolution (6.52 km/s) is sufficient to measure line widths (400 km/s) and the integrated line flux.

We have specified an angular resolution larger than 1 arcsec to measure the total CO emission from our targets and not resolve out any of the emission if observed at higher spatial resolution. The largest angular scales should be 3arcsec since this is larger than the size of our targets. If our targets cannot be observed in configurations C36-1 or C36-2 due to scheduling restrictions, then C36-3 at a resolution of 1.2" is acceptable.

We have computed the integration times needed to detect CO (2-1) based on the well-measured IR bolometric luminosities of our targets. We use the LIR-L'CO relation of Daddi et al (2010) and Genzel et al (2010) valid for normal, MS galaxies. We then reduce the predicted CO luminosities by a factor of 3 based on the observations of local ULIRGs, whose star formation efficiency (SFE=LIR/L'CO) is 3 times smaller than that of local spirals. We estimate the sensitivity requirements and integration times for each individual target to reach a significance of 5. We then group the targets into three categories (science goal I-bright, 2-faint and 3-faint) based on a requirement to achieve a given sensitivity (either 0.3, 0.2 or 0.1 mJy) that reduces the overall overheads. CO is expected to be detected at the following frequencies based on the redshifts of our targets in SG3 (PACS-224:86.96 GHz, PACS-251: 89.18 GHz, PACS-837: 86.83 GHz). Given that our single aim is to detect the level of CO emission in off-MS galaxies, we request a compact configuration of ALMA, yielding a resolution of 3 arcsec; this ensures that we can recover the total flux from each source without the risk of resolving out some of the power. The bandwidth for the required sensitivity is chosen to be 400 km/s that likely matches the typical line width (FWHM) of our sample. The total observing time of SG 3 with ALMA in band-3 is 4.9 hours including overheads.

We use four basebands each of width 1.875 GHz. Two bands are set for the detection of the CO (2-1) line while the other two are set to measure the continuum as secondary to our main objective. Our velocity resolution (6.72 km/s) is sufficient to measure the line widths (400 km/s) and the integrated line flux.

We have specified an angular resolution larger than 1 arcsec to measure the total CO emission from our targets and not resolve out any of the emission if observed at higher spatial resolution. The largest angular scales should be 3arcsec since this is larger than the size of our targets. If our targets cannot be observed in configurations C36-1 or C36-2 due to scheduling restrictions, then C36-3 at a resolution of 1.2" is acceptable.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is unclear whether the most rapidly star-forming galaxies operate in a mode of star formation dissimilar from the majority that populate the so-called Main Sequence (MS). Two scenarios are commonly considered: (1) the sudden accumulation of gas at the bottom of the potential well, due to a major merger, is causing a highly efficient conversion of gas into stars, or (2) outliers may form stars in the same mode (i.e. efficiency) as MS galaxies, but just happen to be exceptionally gas rich. We can directly test this by determining whether the star formation efficiency is different from that of MS galaxies, and if so, whether the distribution of efficiencies is continuous or bimodal. Our NIR spectroscopic survey of star-forming galaxies in COSMOS with z~1.6 using Subaru/FMOS is enabling us to identify galaxies detected by Hershel/PACS and having extreme offsets (>8X) from the MS. We propose to obtain CO measurements for 7 new targets thus reaching a final sample of 10 such galaxies with accurate spectroscopic redshifts and SFRs based on FIR luminosity that builds off our previous ALMA study and lays the groundwork for future (sub)mm studies of outliers at higher spatial resolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Project code: 2012.1.00952.S Title: Molecular gas content of EXTREME outliers from the star-forming main sequence at z ~ 1.5 PI. John Silverman
